questions.text: 1. A cruise ship worker comes with pneumonia, diarrhea, and confusion. Culture on buffered charcoal yeast agar demonstrates the growth of coccobacillus. What is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is caused by a gram-positive organism
Amoxicillin is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a case of Legionnaires' disease caused by Legionella pneumophila. Legionnaire’s disease is associated with hyponatremia in patients. 

Legionella pneumophila is a fastidious, aerobic, gram-negative coccobacillus (Option A). It can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements.

Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc. Human-to-human transmission does not occur (Option C). It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. Hyponatremia is a feature typical of this infection, leading to confusion. It is usually severe in immunocompromised patients.

Diagnosis is by the identification of Legionella antigens in urine by latex agglutination or Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA). Direct fluorescent antibody test and culture on BCYE media can be used. Treatment is by newer macrolides, ciprofloxacin, or tetracycline. Aminoglycoside and beta-lactam antibiotics are ineffective (Option D).

questions.text: 2. A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presents with the multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatic distribution. The lesions are limited to the cutaneous tissues. On microscopy from tissue biopsy, flower-like clusters of conidia as shown in the image below are seen. Which of the following is the best drug for this condition?
questions.solution:
Itraconazole is used in the treatment of cutaneous sporotrichosis.

The presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is Sporothrix schenckii.

Triazoles act by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis. The azole group inhibits the fungal cytochrome P450 enzyme called 14-α-sterol demethylase and results in an impairment of the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol. This results in the depletion of membrane ergosterol.

The azole group of antifungal are grouped into two types :

* Imidazole- clotrimazole, ketoconazole ,luliconazole

* Triazole- Itraconazole, fluconazole, voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole

Other options:

Option B: Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including Candida glabrata and Candida krusei), Scedosporium, and Fusarium.

Option C: Amphotericin B and itraconazole are used for the management of extracutaneous sporotrichosis.

Option D: Posaconazole is used as an oral drug in the treatment of mucormycosis.

questions.text: 3. A 50-year-old diabetic patient presented with cough and breathlessness and a diagnosis of bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is made. The causative organism was found to be Aspergillus fumigatus. Which of the following can be seen on Sabouraud agar on the culture of the organism?
questions.solution:
On the culture of Aspergillus fumigatus on Sabouraud agar, dark-green colored colonies are seen.

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients, and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are other presentations.

This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so the periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include the detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black(Option B). Yellow-green colonies(Option C)are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Intravenous voriconazole, itraconazole, and posaconazole are currently used for the treatment.

questions.text: 4. Which among the following antimicrobial agents is B. cepacia intrinsically resistant to?
questions.solution:
Burkholderia cepacia (B. cepacia) is intrinsically resistant to cefotetan, a second-generation cephalosporin .

B. cepacia complex strains are intrinsically resistant to :

* First and second-generation cephalosporins

* Aminoglycosides

* Polymyxin

* Carboxypenicillins

Although resistance to previously used antibiotics like meropenem and TMP SMX has also been increasing in various highly virulent strains, antimicrobial agents against which B. cepacia is not intrinsically resistant and can be used include: 

* Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Co-trimoxazole) (Option A)

* Meropenem (Option C)

* Doxycycline(Option B), minocycline 

* Chloramphenicol

* Ceftazidime

Patients with cystic fibrosis and chronic granulomatous disease are vulnerable to infection with B. cepacia. Cepacia syndrome is a rapidly fatal syndrome of respiratory distress and septicemia in cystic fibrosis patients. It is also a cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-associated infections, and wound infections.

B. cepacia secretes elastase and possesses components of an injectable toxin-secretion system like that of P. aeruginosa. Its lipopolysaccharide (LPS) is more potent than LPS from P. aeruginosa.

Selective media containing colistin are recommended when culturing the sputum of patients with cystic fibrosis. B. cepacia may take 3 days before colonies are visible. It is oxidase-positive, like all members of the Pseudomonadaceae family.

questions.text: 5. A 5-year-old child presented with lesions on his face as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism of this boy's condition.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a boy presenting with small pearly white umbilicated wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center  is suggestive of infection by Molluscum contagiosum virus, which belongs to the pox virus family.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limiting viral disease of the skin caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. The age of peak incidence is between 2 and 5 years. In children, it is mainly caused by the type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1). There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection. Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

It has an incubation period of 2 weeks to 6 months. The lesions are shiny, pearly white, hemispherical, umbilicated papules that may show a central pore. These may enlarge slowly. Widespread and refractory lesions are seen most commonly in HIV or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. 

It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon is seen, i.e., new lesions develop along a line of trauma.

The diagnosis is usually clear when multiple lesions at different stages of evolution are seen and the classical umbilicated papule is observed. Diagnosis can be confirmed by direct microscopy, histopathology, or molecular analysis.

Treatment is usually not required, and lesions are likely to resolve spontaneously. Stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, and imiquimod. Cryotherapy, when done, needs to be repeated at 3-4 week intervals. Extensive lesions are treated with an antiviral agent like cidofovir.

questions.text: 6. A man presents with rapidly progressive swelling and cellulitis of the hand following a dog bite. Gram stain of the wound exudate shows small Gram-negative coccobacilli with a characteristic bipolar appearance which are oxidase and catalase positive on biochemical testing. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
The organism most likely responsible for this presentation is Pasteurella multocida.

Pasteurella are nonmotile, Gram-negative coccobacilli that appear bipolar on stained smears. These bacteria are aerobes or facultative anaerobes, growing readily on ordinary bacteriologic media at 37°C. All Pasteurella species are oxidase- and catalase-positive, although they differ in other biochemical reactions

P. multocida is found globally in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts of numerous domestic and wild animals. It is a common cause of human wound infections resulting from animal bites, particularly from cats and dogs.

Infections typically present within hours of an animal bite, characterized by acute redness, swelling, and pain. Regional lymphadenopathy is variable, and fever is often low-grade. Pasteurella infections can also manifest as bacteremia or chronic respiratory infections, sometimes without an obvious link to animal exposure.

P. multocida is generally susceptible to most antibiotics. Penicillin G is the preferred drug for P. multocida infections caused by animal bites, with tetracyclines and fluoroquinolones serving as alternative treatments.

Other options:

Option A: Yersinia pestis, despite being gram-negative with a bipolar appearance, is catalase-positive and oxidase-negative. It causes characteristic buboes and is not generally associated with a cellulitis picture.

Option C: Brucella melitensis is usually transmitted via contaminated dairy products and is not associated with the presentation described here. It is a Gram-negative coccobacillus that is catalase and oxidase-positive.

Option D: Campylobacter jejuni is a slender, spirally curved, gram-negative bacillus that can cause reactive arthritis, GBS, and Erythema nodosum.

questions.text: 8. A patient is brought to the casualty with a 10-day history of increasing confusion. Physical examination shows a startle myoclonus. Over the past 12 months, he has had progressive memory deficits. This patient had a VP shunt insertion post meningitis 5 years ago at the same hospital. Lumbar puncture showed normal glucose counts. 4 other patients of this hospital after that procedure have had similar complaints in the past 6 months. What is the likely etiology of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition is likely to be Prion disease, which occurs due to the accumulation of misfolded proteins.

This patient has presented with symptoms of rapidly progressive neurological and memory deficits with current complaints of confusion. 4 other patients with similar complaints make nosocomial cause the likely etiology. The rapid progression of symptoms makes Prion disease, caused by the accumulation of misfolded protein, the likely cause of this condition. The source of the prion infection could have been the surgical equipment that was not adequately sterilized. 

The proteins that make up the prions (PrP) are present even normally in the cells. This normal form, PrPc, is in a predominantly α-helical configuration and is sensitive to proteases. However, the prions (infectious form) are in an abnormal β-pleated configuration and are called PrPSc.

This pathological form is not degradable by proteases and converts the normal form- PrPc to the abnormal form- PrPSc. This abnormal protein gets deposited as plaques, and degeneration of surrounding neuronal and glial tissue occurs, characterized by intracellular vacuoles, leading to a characteristic spongiform encephalopathy. There is no associated inflammatory response to these agents. 

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

* Sporadic (sCJD): Most common;

* Variant (vCJD): Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (mad cow disease), Kuru;

* Familial (fCJD): These individuals carry a PrPc mutation and include Gerstmann-Sträussler- Scheinker syndrome and fatal familial insomnia;

* Iatrogenic (iCJD): Maybe seen occurring after corneal transplantation, liver transplantation, use of contaminated neurosurgical instruments, use of cadaver-derived hormones, or stereotactic depth electrodes. 

Clinically, CJD presents with predominantly CNS manifestations with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus (startle myoclonus is common), ataxia, akinetic mutism, visual disturbances, and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction. Insomnia, apathy, and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen. 

CSF is predominantly normal but may show a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. EEG may show periodic triphasic or multiphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes or spike-wave patterns. MRI on FLAIR sequencing and diffusion-weighted imaging will show increased intensity in the basal ganglia region and a characteristic 'cortical ribboning', in sporadic CJD. Diagnosis of CJD can be established on brain biopsy either by measuring PrPSc or by demonstrating the characteristic neuropathological features of spongiform encephalopathy.

Management is mainly supportive as the disease is usually fatal within a year of the onset of symptoms. 

Other options:

Option A: Chronic bacterial meningitis causes features of raised ICP and is associated with a decreased glucose count in the CSF. This patient's startle myoclonus with a history of a neurological procedure makes a diagnosis of Prion disease more likely.

Option C: Blockage of the shunt system presents with features of raised ICP as there is no outlet for drainage of CSF. This patient's only symptoms are progressive memory deficits with a history of VP shunt insertion. This makes a prion disease the likely etiology. 

Option D: Surgical error during the procedure could have presented more acutely and not after 5 years.

questions.text: 9. A 17-year-old student develops infectious mononucleosis. About 15 days later, he develops a high fever, and his sore throat worsens. He has lost his ability to swallow and has severe neck and chest pain. Upon admission, he has signs of septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein. Which is the organism most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest the diagnosis of Lemierre’s disease. Fusobacterium necrophorum is most likely to be involved in this condition.

Fusobacterium necrophorum is a Gram-negative anaerobic bacillus that is very pleomorphic. It is involved in very severe oropharyngeal infections that can progress to a complicated and life-threatening condition called Lemierre’s disease. It is most commonly caused by Fusobacterium necrophorum. However, species of Bacteroides, Eikenella, Streptococcus, and Peptostreptococcus may also be implicated.

Lemierre’s disease often occurs after infectious mononucleosis in older children and young adults. It is characterized by internal jugular vein septic thrombophlebitis. This progresses to abscesses of the lungs, mediastinum, pleural space, and liver with sepsis. It presents with pharyngitis that is not resolving, associated with rigors, neck pain, and swelling.

Other options:

Option A: Prevotella melaninogenica  is an anaerobic gram-negative rod usually associated with dental abscess or aspiration pneumonia

Option B: Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron is an anaerobic gram negative in human gut.

Option C: Peptococcus niger is an anaerobic gram-positive coccus found. in skin, GIT and mouth.

questions.text: 10. A 50-year-old man underwent renal transplantation 3 months ago. He presents with a gradual rise in serum creatinine. Urine cytology shows the presence of cells, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following viruses is most likely implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The BK polyomavirus is most likely implicated in this scenario.

BK virus is a human polyomavirus that reactivates in immunocompromised patients, particularly renal transplant recipients. It causes polyomavirus-associated nephropathy (PVAN) and hemorrhagic cystitis in transplant patients.

The cells shown in the image are Decoy cells, which are found in the urine cytology and are characteristic of BK virus infection.

Diagnostic modalities for BK virus include:

* Renal biopsy: A definitive diagnosis is established by histologic examination of renal biopsy specimens. These specimens show characteristic histopathologic changes such as inflammatory infiltrates, fibrosis, and tubular injury, along with positive immunohistochemistry for BK virus.

* PCR: Identification of BK viremia (BK virus DNA in blood) via PCR, combined with features of nephropathy, is suggestive of the diagnosis.

* Asymptomatic BK viruria: The detection of BK virus DNA in urine is a less specific finding and may not be clinically significant.

* Decoy cells in urine cytology are characteristic of BK virus infection.

Other Options

Option A: JC virus is a polyomavirus like BK, but its primary site of pathology is the CNS, causing progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML).

Option C: Adenovirus can infect the urinary tract and occasionally cause hemorrhagic cystitis, especially in immunocompromised patients. However, it does not cause decoy cells in urine and is a DNA virus unrelated to polyomavirus nephropathy.

Option D: CMV is a DNA virus of the Herpesviridae family. It can cause systemic illness, including interstitial nephritis, but decoy cells are not characteristic.

questions.text: 11. A 20-year-old female patient presented with complaints of burning micturition and fever with chills for three days. After a detailed workup, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection caused by Staphylococcus saprophyticus. Which of the following is correct regarding the biochemical properties of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus saprophyticus is coagulase-negative and novobiocin-resistant.

Coagulase-negative Staphylococci are a part of normal human flora, and they include S. epidermidis, S. haemolyticus, and S. lugdunensis, apart from S. saprophyticus.

Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a gram-positive, coagulase-negative staphylococcus. It is non-pigmented, novobiocin-resistant, and non-hemolytic on blood agar. It is a leading cause of cystitis in women. It is a part of the normal flora of human skin and the periurethral area, and thus causes cystitis in women who are sexually active.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a gram-positive, coagulase-negative staphylococcus. It is the most common cause of coagulase-negative staphylococcus infection in humans. It is novobiocin-sensitive and also causes infective endocarditis in heart valve patients.

questions.text: 12. A 35-year-old man developed generalized muscle spasms a few days after sustaining a puncture wound to his leg. The microscopic image of the causative organism is shown below. Which of the following is not indicated in the treatment of infection with the following organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of generalized muscle spasms following a puncture wound, with the given image showing Clostridium tetani, suggests a diagnosis of tetanus. Hyperbaric oxygen is not indicated in the treatment of tetanus. 

The image shows slender, gram-positive bacilli with terminal spores that are spherical, bulging, and have a drumstick appearance, typical of Clostridium tetani. It is the causative agent of tetanus.

The treatment of tetanus involves cleaning and debridement of necrotic material in the wound. Metronidazole (400 mg rectally or 500 mg IV every 6 h for 7 days) is preferred for antibiotic therapy. Antitoxin should be given early to deactivate any circulating tetanus toxin and prevent its uptake into the nervous system. Two preparations are available- human tetanus immune globulin (TIG) and equine antitoxin. TIG is the preparation of choice, as there is a lower chance of anaphylaxis. A single IM dose (500–5000 IU) is given, with a portion injected around the wound.

Clostridium tetani secretes 2 types of toxins, namely, tetanolysin and tetanospasmin. Of these, tetanospasmin has been implicated in the pathogenesis of tetanus.

Tetanospasmin acts pre-synaptically and specifically blocks synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord, at inhibitory terminals that use glycine and GABA as neurotransmitters. This abolition of spinal inhibition causes the uncontrolled spread of impulses initiated everywhere in the central nervous system. This results in muscle rigidity and spasms due to the simultaneous contraction of agonists and antagonists, in the absence of reciprocal inhibition.

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is indicated in gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens.

questions.text: 13. Causative organism for black piedra is ______
questions.solution:
Piedraia hortae is the causative organism for black piedra.

Piedra is a fungal infection of the hair characterized by the presence of firm, irregular nodules along the hair shaft. The nodules consist of fungal elements that are cemented together on the hair.



Other options: 

Option A: Trichosporon beigelii causes white piedra.



Option C: Tinea nigra is a localized fungal infection of the stratum corneum, especially affecting the palms. It produces brownish/blackish macular lesions. It is caused by Exophiala werneckii.

questions.text: 14. Which of the following statements is false regarding bacterial cell wall?

Teichoic acid is present in cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria
Region II of LPS is core polysaccharide

questions.text: 15. A 34-year-old man living in the UK is planning to travel to India. His doctor advises him to take the oral typhoid vaccine. Which of the following days are included in the schedule?
questions.solution:
Days 1, 3, and 5 are included in the schedule of oral typhoid vaccine (Ty21a vaccine), if day 1 is the first dose of the vaccine. In other words, it should be given on alternate days.

Ty21a vaccine is a live oral typhoid vaccine containing a mutated Salmonella typhi Ty21a. This strain lacks the enzyme UDP- galactose- 4 epimerases. It initiates an infection after ingestion, but the strain is self-destructible. Hence does not cause a serious illness.  

The schedule is 3 doses on alternate days, i.e., on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day. The capsules are enteric coated and taken an hour before food. No antibiotic should be taken during the schedule. Oral typhoid vaccine can also be given in a 4-day alternate day regimen.

questions.text:
16. Arrange the following in order for the replication of hepatitis B virus.

* Uncoating

* DNA synthesis

* Transcription

* Enveloping

* Closed circular DNA

* Encapsidation
questions.solution:
The correct sequence in the hepatitis B viral replication is 1,5,3,6,2,4: uncoating > closed circular DNA > transcription > encapsidation > DNA synthesis > enveloping.

The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus with an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. The viral genome consists of two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand) is incomplete resulting in partially double-stranded and partially single-stranded DNA. The steps in replication of HBV can be summarised as follows:

* The virus first attaches to the host and gets uncoated.

* The partially double-stranded DNA is converted to covalently closed circular (ccc) DNA in the nucleus.

* The cccDNA serves as the template for the production of HBV mRNAs and pre-genomic RNA.

* The pre-genomic RNA is encapsidated by newly synthesized HBcAg core particles.

* Within the encapsidated core, RNA serves as a template for the HBV reverse transcriptase which is a part of the polymerase gene to synthesise negative-strand DNA. Positive-strand DNA synthesis starts but does not proceed to completion within the core, resulting in a variable-length positive-strand DNA.

* Core particles containing these DNA replicative intermediates acquire HBsAg-containing envelopes to complete the process.

questions.text:
17. A patient with chronic fatigue ,weight loss and cough is diagnosed with Pneumocystis pneumonia. On further investigation, he is found to be HIV positive. Which of the following genera does the HIV virus belong to?

HIV - Human immunodeficiency virus
questions.solution:
HIV belongs to the lentivirus genus, in the retroviridae family. 

The retrovirus family is classified into 7 genera which includes lentiviruses, which is the genus that HIV belongs to. Pneumocystis pneumonia is an AIDS-defining illness and whenever it is diagnosed in isolation, the patient must be investigated for HIV-AIDS.

Lentiviruses possess a linear, positive sense, single stranded RNA genome. They possess a glycoprotein envelope containing a spherical virion with a cylindrical core. They use reverse transcriptase for replication and protease for maturation. Lentiviruses contain the four genes gag, pro, pol, and env required for a replicating retrovirus.  

Genes such as gag, env and pol code for structural proteins. Gag gene codes for core and shell protein p55, which is cleaved to p15, p18 and p24. Env gene codes for envelope glycoprotein gp160 which is cleaved to gp120 and gp41. Pol gene codes for the enzymes polymerase, reverse transcriptase, protease, and endonuclease.

Major antigens of HIV include envelope antigens (gp120, gp41), shell antigen (p18), core antigens (p24, p15, p55) and polymerase antigens (p31, p51, p66).



Other options: 

Option A: Alpharetrovirus is a genus in the retroviridae family, and does not include HIV.

Option B: Deltaretrovirus is a genus in the retroviridae family, which includes human T-lymphotropic viruses (HTLV) but not HIV.

Option D: Flavivirus is a genus that includes arboviruses such as West Nile virus, Zika and Yellow Fever.

questions.text: 18. A 17-year-old boy came with complaints of toothache for a few days. Oral examination revealed the presence of dental caries. The bacteria isolated from the lesion demonstrates alpha hemolysis and the growth was not inhibited by optochin. Which of the following bacteria is commonly implicated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of dental caries with bacteria showing alpha hemolysis and optochin resistance is suggestive of Streptococcus mutans.

Streptococcus mutans belongs to the viridans group of streptococci, and they are a common organism causing dental caries. Streptococcus mutans breaks down the dietary sucrose, resulting in the production of acid and a tough adhesive dextran. The acid damages dentine while the dextrans bind together with food debris, epithelial cells, mucus, and bacteria to form dental plaques, leading to the formation of dental caries.

Viridans streptococci show alpha hemolysis on blood agar and are resistant to optochin. It includes:

* Streptococci mitis 

* Streptococci mutans

* Streptococci salvarius

* Streptococci sanguis (causes sub-acute bacterial endocarditis)

Other options:

Option B- Streptococcus pyogenes are beta-hemolytic and they mainly cause upper respiratory tract infection, pyoderma, rheumatic fever, and glomerulonephritis. 

Option C- Streptococcus bovis are gamma hemolytic and they mainly cause endocarditis. 

Option D- Streptoccocus agalactiae are beta-hemolytic and they mainly cause neonatal meningitis, septicemia, and urinary tract infection.

questions.text: 19. A 35 year old HIV positive man hailing from a village infested with bamboo rats presents with fever, weight loss, dyspnea, and hepatosplenomegaly. He was diagnosed with a fungal disease whose Lactophenol cotton blue staining showed the following appearance. Which of the following organisms is implicated here?
questions.solution:
The most likely causative organism from the given LPCB image showing brush/broom appearance in an immunocompromised individual with exposure to bamboo rats is Talaromyces marneffei (Penicillium marneffei).

T.marneffei is a dimorphic fungus that causes talaromycosis (penicilliosis). It is commonly seen in individuals with advanced AIDS. Diagnosed by blood culture, which shows a mold with a powdery surface and characteristic red pigment that diffuses into the agar. It shows yeast form at 37 °C and mold at 25°C. Yeast forms appear as ellipsoidal cells with central septation. This indicates that these organisms divide via transverse fission rather than budding. The mold forms show septate hyphae with branched conidiophores in two rows resembling a brush or a broom. 

Clinical features include fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Umbilicated papules that resemble molluscum contagiosum may also be seen.Mild and moderate infections can be treated with itraconazole. Amphotericin B is recommended for severe infections.

questions.text: 20. A 25-year-old man presents with painful swelling and discharge from the right ear after swimming in seawater. Gram stain of the purulent discharge reveals Gram-negative curved rods. The bacteria grow in media having a salt concentration of more than 10%. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the most likely cause is Vibrio alginolyticus.

The clinical symptoms of painful swelling and discharge from the right ear after swimming in seawater are suggestive of acute otitis media.

Gram stain revealing Gram-negative curved rods, and the growth of the bacteria in media having a salt concentration of more than 10% is suggestive of the involvement of Vibrio alginolyticus.

Vibrio alginolyticus can cause eye, ear, and wound infections. Reported cases include otitis externa, otitis media, and conjunctivitis. It rarely causes bacteremia in immunocompromised individuals.

This bacterium is notably salt-tolerant, capable of growing in concentrations exceeding 10%. Identification can be performed using automated methods like MALDI-TOF and VITEK.

Infections are typically self-limiting; severe cases respond well to antibiotics (such as tetracycline) and drainage.

Option B: Vibrio cholerae causes cholera. It is non-halophilic.

questions.text: 22. A farmer presents with lesions on his hand as seen in the image below. He gives a history of a thorn prick a few weeks ago. Histological examination of the lesion showed sclerotic bodies. What is the probable diagnosis?

questions.text: 23. A microbiologist carries out a milk ring test which gives a blue ring at the top and leaves the milk unstained. Which of the following option is true regarding the most likely organism responsible for this test?
questions.solution:
The appearance of the blue ring at the top and unstained milk is indicative of a positive Milk Ring Test (MRT). The most likely organism giving a positive MRT is the Brucella species. They are Non-motile and aerobic.

Features of Brucellae:

* They are non-motile, non-capsulated(Option D), and non-sporing. They are Gram-negative and non-acid-fast (Option B)

* They are strict aerobes

* They are catalase-positive, oxidase-positive (except for B.neotomae and B.ovis, which are negative) and urease-positive (Option C). Nitrates are reduced to nitrites. MR and VP tests are negative

Milk Ring Test:

*  It is used for the detection of infected animals in dairy, farms, etc. 

* A sample of whole milk is mixed with a drop of Brucella antigen and incubated at 70 °C for 40–50 min.

* If antibodies are present in the milk the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the milk unstained (MRT positive). If antibodies are absent, the milk remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text: 25. A 35-year-old pet shop owner was admitted to the ICU with severe pneumonia. Bronchoalveolar lavage revealed Levinthal–Cole–Lillie bodies. Which of the following is the infectious form of the organism implicated?
questions.solution:
Levinthal-Cole-Lilly bodies are seen in Chlamydia psittaci infections, the infective form of which is the elementary body.

Chlamydiae exist in two distinct morphological forms:

* The elementary body is the small, extracellular and infectious stage, measuring about 200–300 nm. It has a rigid trilaminar wall resembling that of Gram-negative bacteria and contains a dense nucleoid.

* The reticulate body (option D), earlier termed the initial body, is the larger intracellular replicative stage, around 500–1000 nm. Its fragile, flexible wall accounts for its pleomorphic appearance.

All chlamydia species exhibit a biphasic developmental cycle where the environmentally stable elementary body(EB) acts as the infectious form. The elementary body (EB) binds to heparin sulfate glycoproteins and is taken up by clathrin-mediated endocytosis. Once inside the host cell, it transforms into the larger reticulate body, which multiplies by binary fission; eventually forming a cytoplasmic inclusion inside the host cells that is filled with EBs. These EBs are released later to infect new host cells, thus completing a 48-72 hour development cycle.



Other options:

Option A: Plerocercoid larva is the infective form for Diphyllobothrium latum

Option C:  Oocyst is infective for various protozoan parasites, not Chlamydia sp.

questions.text: 26. Through which receptor does the virus responsible for infectious mononucleosis enter the epithelial cells of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis. EBV enters pharyngeal epithelial cells through CD 21 (or CR2) receptors. They are the same as those for the C3d component of complement.

EBV may lead to the following presentations:

* Infectious mononucleosis

* Burkitt’s lymphoma

* Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

* Lymphomas in immunodeficient persons such as AIDS or transplant recipients.

EBV multiplies inside the lymphocyte in two ways. First, they immortalize the lymphocytes that they infect leading to uncontrolled growth. The cells produce different types of immunoglobulins as a result. The second way they damage the lymphocyte is by causing lysis leading to the release of virions. 

In infectious mononucleosis, the infected B lymphocytes express EBV antigens on the cell surface. The atypical lymphocyte seen in EBV infections is due to T lymphocytes transforming in response to the infected B lymphocytes.

Other options:

Option A: CD 1 receptors are associated with thymocytes and Langerhans cells. 

Option B: CD 3 receptors are associated with the T cell antigen receptor complex.

Option C: CD 8 receptors are associated with suppressor/cytotoxic T cells.

questions.text: 28. A child with sickle cell anemia presents with fever and fatigue for 1 week. Blood tests revealed a hemoglobin level of 5 g/dL, reticulocytopenia, and normal platelet and leukocyte counts. Parvovirus B19 serology test is positive. What is the pathophysiology behind the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow infiltration by malignant cells

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with sickle cell anemia presenting with fever, fatigue, and investigations revealing hemoglobin of 5 g/dL, reticulocytopenia, and a positive parvovirus B19 serology test is suggestive of aplastic crisis. It is due to erythroid progenitor cell destruction.

Aplastic crisis may be seen in patients with underlying chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, or hereditary spherocytosis. Dysmorphic erythrocytes in sickle cell disease are susceptible to parvovirus B19 infection. The P antigen on erythroid and endothelial cells is the receptor for the virus. 

Patients with aplastic crisis present with fever, malaise, tachycardia, and dyspnea due to profound anemia. There is an acute, severe drop in hemoglobin and associated reticulocytopenia due to progenitor cell destruction. 

Parvovirus B19 is a small, single-stranded DNA virus. Infection can be transmitted via respiratory droplets or by vertical transmission. In children, it can lead to erythema infectiosum, characterized by fever, bright red facial flushing resembling "slapped cheeks" and a widespread rash across the trunk and limbs, as illustrated below.



In utero infection with parvovirus B19 is associated with hydrops fetalis and possible fetal demise. Parvovirus B19 infection in adults can manifest as infectious arthritis or pure red cell aplasia, notably in patients with compromised immunity.

Other options:

Option B: Autoantibody mediated hemolysis is seen in patients with conditions chronic lymphocytic leukemia and viral infections which precipitate autoimmune hemolytic anemia. It is not seen in parvovirus infection. 

Option C and D: Suppression of erythropoietin production and malignant infiltration are not the mechanism of aplastic crisis in parvovirus B19 patients.

questions.text: 29. The etiopathogenesis of which of the following conditions does not depend predominantly upon the production of mycotoxins?
questions.solution:
In ABPA, inhalation of Aspergillus fumigatus spores provokes a type I and/or type III hypersensitivity reaction and is not associated with the production of mycotoxins. Fungal presence is required for its pathogenesis though no tissue invasion occurs.

Mycotoxicoses are diseases caused by toxic secondary metabolites known as mycotoxins. Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects. These diseases do not require fungal infection or invasion of tissue by the fungus.

Examples:

* Aflatoxins are produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as A. flavus in contaminated groundnuts, corn, and peas.

* Ergot alkaloids produced by Claviceps purpurea in contaminated rye

* Fusarium toxins

questions.text: 30. A 25-year-old man presents with a slowly enlarging woody subcutaneous swelling over his face following an insect bite. After a thorough workup, he was diagnosed with Entomophthoromycoses. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Entomophthoromycoses is caused by Conidiobolus coronatus.

Entomophthoromycoses, is a rare disease caused by Conidiobolus coronatus and Basidiobolus ranarum. These are saprophytic zygomycetes found in decaying vegetation and in the intestines of many reptiles and amphibians.

Clinically, a painless subcutaneous nodule develops, which can enlarge to involve a whole limb or large areas of the body. These lesions are now thought to be acquired through insect bites.

Diagnosis is made by culture of the causative fungi and histopathology, which shows short, broad, fragmented hyphae with beak-like projections. Treatment is challenging and may require surgery, followed by antifungals like itraconazole or terbinafine hydrochloride for two to three months.

questions.text: 31. In liquid culture media, the growth of virulent strains of Mycobacteria is distinguished from that of avirulent strains by

choices.text: Production of rough, buff, and tough colonies

questions.solution:
In liquid culture media, the growth of virulent strains of Mycobacteria is distinguished from that of non-virulent strains by the formation of serpentine cords.

Serpentine cords are rope-like clumps of M. tuberculosis seen in liquid culture. They result from the action of cord factor (trehalose dimycolate), a glycolipid virulence factor. Cord factor is responsible for inhibiting neutrophil migration, inducing TNF-α release, and contributing to granuloma formation.

Avirulent strains grow in a more dispersed manner (Option B) in liquid media.

Other options: 

Option C: Production of pigment is seen in photochromogens/scotochromogens (M. kansasii, M. marinum), not a marker of virulence.

Option D: Rough, buff, and tough colonies are produced on Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium, which is a solid medium.

questions.text: 32. A 40-year-old man living in a rat-infested apartment presented with a history of fever, vomiting, hematuria, and decreased urine output and was diagnosed with hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS). Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) is caused by Hantaviruses, which are rodent-borne viruses that are transmitted by inhalation of the virus contained in dried excreta of rodents. They are the natural pathogens of rodents like mice, rats, and moles. No human-to-human transmission is seen. 

HFRS presents with acute kidney injury, hemorrhages, fever, and circulatory collapse. It is caused by the following members of the hantaviruses: Hantaan, Dobrava virus, Puumala virus, and Seoul virus. 

Hantaviruses can also cause Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome, which is caused by another member, Sin nombre virus, prevalent in America. 

Diagnosis is made by the detection of viral RNA by RT-PCR. Management of HFRS involves vasopressor support with modest crystalloids, IV albumin, and timely renal replacement to avoid pulmonary edema. Hypertension must be controlled to prevent intracranial hemorrhage. IV ribavirin, if started within 4 days, reduces case fatality and morbidity. With good supportive care, survivors usually recover fully.

questions.text: 33. An unimmunized boy developed conjunctivitis and bluish-white spots on his buccal mucosa. Four days later, he developed a rash, as shown below. What is the incubation period for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of conjunctivitis, bluish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Koplik's spots), and the image showing widespread maculopapular rash are suggestive of measles. The approximate period between the exposure to the infection and the appearance of symptoms (incubation period) is 10 to 14 days. 

Measles is an infection caused by Paramyxovirus which is a single-stranded lipid enveloped RNA virus. It is spread 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of rash through body secretions. The patient should be isolated for a week from the onset of the rash to prevent spreading. Infected cells are found fused together to form multinucleated giant cells called Warthin - Finkeldey cells. 

The image below shows a slide of a lymph node biopsy showing a Warthin–Finkeldey giant cell:



The clinical features are mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. The Koplik spots are red lesions with bluish-white spots seen in the inner cheeks at the level of premolars. 

The image below shows Koplik spots:



The red maculopapular rashes begin on the forehead, behind the ears, and on the upper neck on the 4th day. It then spreads towards the torso, and extremities and reaches the palms and soles. 

The image of the maculopapular rash is shown below:





The diagnosis is mainly made clinically but serological demonstration of IgM antibodies and IgG antibodies are also used. Complications are pneumonia, croup, tracheitis etc. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a nearly fatal complication of chronic measles diagnosed by elevated IgG levels in cerebrospinal fluid. 

Measles can be prevented by active immunisation. Live attenuated vaccine is given subcutaneously except for immunocompromised and pregnant women. According to WHO it requires at least 96% immunisation coverage under one year of age for eradication.

34. A truck driver presents to the dermatology clinic with painful lesions on his genitals. On examination, there were clusters of vesicles with an erythematous base. A smear is prepared from the lesion and stained accordingly, shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?

* Type 2 is most commonly responsible for the given condition

* Type 1 remains latent primarily in the sacral ganglia

* Type 1 infection confers complete protection against type 2

* Postnatal infection is more commonly due to type 1

* Infectivity of type 2 is more temperature-sensitive than that of type 1
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing clusters of vesicles with an erythematous base and smear shows Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells is seen in genital herpes caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) which can be Type 1 (HHV 1) or type 2 (HHV 2). Statements 1, 4, and 5 are true about the two types of HSV.

The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method. Smears are prepared from the lesions, from the base of vesicles, and stained with 1 % aqueous solution of toluidine blue 'O ' for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground glass' chromatin, known as Tzanck cells are seen.

The given condition is genital herpes, which may be caused by both types of HSV but is more commonly caused by Type 2. (Statement 1)

HSV 1 is usually isolated from lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact or droplet spread from cases or carriers. HSV 2 is responsible for majority of genital herpes infections and is commonly transmitted venereally.

Differentiating features between the two types is mostly demonstrated in a laboratory set-up where the infectivity of type 2 is more temperature sensitive than that of type 1. (Statement 5)

Transmission :

The virus enters through defects in the skin or mucous membranes and enters cutaneous nerve fibres and is transported intra-axonally to the ganglia where it replicates. The virus remains latent in the ganglia, particularly the trigeminal (type 1) and the sacral (type 2) nerves to be reactivated periodically causing recurrent oral and genital lesions. (Statement 2)

The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers . They heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead.

HSV 2 infection confers some protection against HSV 1, but not vice versa. (Statement 3)

The clinical course depends on the site of the infection, age and immune status of the host and the type of virus. It can either be cutaneous, mucosal, ophthalmic, neuologic, visceral, genetic or congenital.

Transplacental infection can occur with both types but is quite rare. Infection can occur during birth if the mother has genital lesions due to HSV 2. Cesarean section is done to prevent infection. Postnatal infection is more commonly due to type 1 (Statement 4). The mortality rate of neonatal herpes is quite high and may leave neurological impairments.

All of the above are virulence factors of Candida albicans except glucuronoxylomannan (GXM).

GXM is the capsular polysaccharide of Cryptococcus. It is seen as a patchy to confluent, whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. questions.text: 37. A 45-year-old immunocompromised male presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and multiple nodular lung infiltrates. For culture, a technique using paraffin as the sole carbon source is employed to selectively isolate the organism responsible for the clinical presentation. Which of the following organisms is most likely?
questions.solution:
The most likely organism responsible for the clinical presentation among the given options is Nocardia asteroides.

Nocardia species are aerobic, gram-positive, catalase-positive, and urease-positive. They are weakly acid-fast because they stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when decolourized with 1–4% sulfuric acid instead of the stronger acid-alcohol decolorant.

They can be cultured on various media, including brain heart infusion agar and Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA). Incubation should be at 37°C for 2 days to 2 weeks. Colonies are typically creamy, wrinkled, pigmented (orange or pink), and firmly adherent to the medium. Some colonies exhibit abundant aerial growth, giving them a cotton wool ball-like appearance.

To recover Nocardia from samples containing Actinomadura and Streptomyces, the following methods can be employed:

* Selective Media: Buffered yeast extract containing polymyxin and vancomycin. Sabouraud dextrose agar with chloramphenicol.

* Paraffin Bait Technique: Media utilizing paraffin as the sole carbon source are effective for isolating nocardiae from soil and clinical samples.

* Lowenstein–Jensen Medium: Produces moist, glabrous colonies, which helps differentiate Nocardia from mycobacteria.

Inhalation is the primary route of bacterial exposure. Infections caused by Nocardia include cutaneous, subcutaneous, or systemic lesions. It may lead to local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions. Systemic nocardiosis occurs more often in immunodeficient persons and is usually caused by N.asteroides. It manifests primarily as pulmonary disease, pneumonia, lung abscess, or other lesions resembling tuberculosis. 

Risk factors for pulmonary nocardiosis include long-term corticosteroid therapy, HIV infection (usually in patients with CD4 count < µ250/L), haematological malignancies, and bone marrow transplantation. Extrapulmonary manifestations may involve the brain, kidneys, and other organs.

Diagnosis is by microscopy of sputum, bronchoalveolar lavage specimens, and tissue biopsy. Gram stain shows beaded Gram-positive filamentous rods. In Modified ZN staining, they are weakly acid-fast. 

The drug of choice for nocardiosis is cotrimoxazole. In severe cases, 3rd-generation cephalosporins/ carbapenems and amikacin are recommended.

questions.text: 38. A 6-year-old boy presents with fever, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea with blood and mucus. Stool culture grows a non-motile, non-lactose-fermenting Gram-negative bacillus. Which of the following virulence factors helps these bacilli to invade the intestinal mucosal epithelium?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of bacillary dysentery caused by Shigella. These bacilli enter the intestinal mucosal epithelium with the help of Ipa proteins. 

Shigellae are Gram-negative rods, typically measuring 0.5 x 1-3 µm. These bacteria are non-motile, non-sporing, and non-capsulated, though fimbriae may be present.

Mannitol fermentation is crucial for classifying Shigellae, which are traditionally categorized into mannitol-fermenting and non-fermenting species. Shigella flexneri, Shigella boydii, and Shigella sonnei ferment mannitol, whereas Shigella dysenteriae does not.

Except for Shigella sonnei, which is a late lactose fermentor, lactose and sucrose are generally not fermented by shigellae.

Shigella is one of the most important causes of bacillary dysentery.

Transmission:

* Common routes: Ingestion via contaminated fingers (most frequent), food, or water.

* Less common: Flies.

* Rare: Sexual transmission (observed in homosexual individuals).

Infective Dose: As few as 10–100 bacilli can initiate the disease, likely due to their ability to survive gastric acidity.

Pathogenesis:

* Entry via M cells: Bacilli enter the intestinal mucosa through M cells and are then engulfed by macrophages.

* Macrophage release: Macrophages subsequently release the bacilli, triggering the recruitment of inflammatory cells.

* Inflammatory response: These inflammatory cells release cytokines, leading to acute colitis, a characteristic symptom of shigellosis.

* Invasion factors: A large virulence plasmid dictates invasion, coding for critical virulence factors such as Ipa proteins and the type III secretion system.

* Direct cell-to-cell spread: Shigellae spread between host cells by inducing actin polymerization, a process mediated by IcsA proteins.

Toxins:

Exotoxins: Some Shigella serotypes produce enterotoxins.

* Shigella enterotoxin (ShET): Structurally similar to cholera toxin, primarily found in S. flexneri 2a.

* Shiga toxin: A cytotoxin produced by S. dysenteriae type 1. It is structurally and functionally similar to the verocytotoxin of EHEC. It inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 60S ribosome. This toxin exacerbates local vascular damage in the intestine and can affect internal organs, such as the kidneys and brain.

Endotoxin: Functions similarly to other gram-negative endotoxins, inducing intestinal inflammation.

Other Options

Option A: Shiga toxin- A cytotoxin produced by S. dysenteriae type 1. It inhibits protein synthesis by targeting the 60S ribosome. It causes hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), watery/bloody diarrhea in some cases, but it is not responsible for mucosal invasion.

Option C: Lipid A- part of lipopolysaccharide, triggers inflammation and fever, not invasion.

Option D: Capsule- Shigellae are non-capsulated.

questions.text: 41. A veterinarian presented to the clinic with fever, malaise, and headache. On examination, a lesion is seen on his arm as shown in the below image. Later the patient developed sepsis. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin in a veterinarian is strongly suggestive of cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis where the toxin acts by the increase in cAMP.

Bacillus anthracis is a large, gram-positive bacillus. It is non-motile and capsulated with a characteristic polypeptide capsule made of poly-γ-d-glutamic acid. 

Bacillus anthracis may cause:

* Cutaneous anthrax: It is caused by contact with infected animal/ animal products. It is seen in tanners and hide-porters. At the site of entry of organism or spores, a papule develops which further develops into a vesicle. It later breaks down into an ulcer with a black, central, necrotic eschar surrounded by edematous skin. The lesion is also called a 'malignant pustule'. A majority of the patients tend to recover spontaneously. However, some patients may succumb to septicemia or meningitis.

* Pulmonary anthrax (Wool sorter’s disease): It is caused by inhaling spores. It is seen in wool sorters. The infection from the lung spreads to the mediastinal lymph nodes and causes hemorrhagic mediastinitis and sepsis. 

* Gastrointestinal anthrax: It is caused rarely, by ingesting infected animals. 

Virulence factors of Bacillus anthracis include:

* Polypeptide capsule which is anti-phagocytic.

* Toxins that are made of three proteins-

* Protective antigen (PA)- Binds to specific cell receptors and mediates entry of edema factor and lethal factor into the cell.

* Edema factor (EF)- Is an adenylate cyclase, which is activated only inside the target cells, leading to intracellular accumulation of cyclic AMP and causing tissue edema.

* Lethal factor (LF)- Causes tissue death.

Option A: Diptheria toxin and Pseudomonas acts by inhibition of elongation factor-2 (EF-2).

Option C: Shiga toxin inhibits protein synthesis by inhibition of 60S ribosomal subunit.

Option D: Some strains of Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) produce a heat-stable toxin that acts by an increase in cGMP.

questions.text: 42. A truck driver presents with a painless, circumscribed ulcer over the penis. He had unprotected sexual intercourse two weeks ago. Examination reveals a non-tender ulcer with an indurated base. Exudate shows the following picture on microscopy. What type of motility is exhibited by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative agent is Treponema pallidum, which exhibits corkscrew motility.

The clinical vignette of a painless, non-tender, circumscribed ulcer over the penis with an indurated base that developed subsequent to unprotected sexual intercourse, and the finding on darkfield microscopy are suggestive of primary syphilis.

It is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete that is actively motile. The motility is best observed on dark ground or phase-contrast microscopy.

The movement is described as corkscrew-like with the organism moving backward and forward while rotating around the long axis. In addition, secondary curves are observed to appear and disappear, as the organism moves.

Primary syphilis occurs subsequent to inoculation of treponema pallidum following sexual contact. It manifests as a local, nontender ulcer over the genitalia called a hard chancre, in 2-10 weeks. 

It can be diagnosed using VDRL, RPR test and can be confirmed by FTA – ABS testing or TPHA, TPI testing.

The bacteria can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. Smear specimens are stained using Fontana stain and pathological tissues are stained using Levaditi stain. Silver impregnation technique can also be used. 

Other options : 

Option B: Darting motility is exhibited by Vibrio cholerae. It is the causative agent of cholera, an acute diarrheal disease characterized by vomiting and stool that is colorless and watery called 'rice water stool'.

Option C: Gliding motility is exhibited by Mycoplasma. It can cause primary atypical pneumonia and genital infections in humans.

Option D: Tumbling motility is exhibited by Listeria monocytogenes. It is the causative agent of listeriosis, which can manifest as meningitis or sepsis in neonates, meningoencephalitis in the elderly, and immunocompromised.

43. A patient who had taken multiple courses of antibiotics suffers from recurrent diarrhoea. Stool ELISA detects glutamate dehydrogenase, and PCR for toxin A is done to confirm the diagnosis. The patient undergoes a fecal microbiota transplant(FMT). Which of the following statements about this condition are true?

* FMT works by using harmless bacteria to displace the pathogenic bacterium.

* FMT kills Bacteroides and Firmicutes and reduces their count in the gut.

* CCFA agar is a selective medium for the causative organism.

* The causative organism is a Gram-positive obligate aerobe
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 3 are true in the given clinical scenario of Clostridium Difficile infection for which the patient has undergone fecal microbiota transplant.

Fecal microbiota transplant (FMT) works on the concept of bacterial interference, that is, using harmless bacteria to displace pathogenic bacteria. (Statement 1 )

Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT), or stool transplant, involves transferring fecal bacteria from a healthy donor to a recipient. This procedure has been successfully employed to treat patients with C. difficile infection. FMT reintroduces beneficial microorganisms, specifically from the Bacteroides and Firmicutes phyla, to restore the balance of the colonic microbiota. (Statement 2)

Clostridium difficile, a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus (statement 4) is the most common infective cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Majority of the cases occur in the elderly with comorbidities within 1-6 weeks of antibiotic therapy. The symptoms include lower abdominal pain and watery diarrhoea. Rarely, it may progress to pseudomembranous colitis.

Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) is diagnosed primarily through stool testing for C. difficile toxins A or B. Initial screening commonly uses glutamate dehydrogenase (GDH) detection or PCR for C. difficile nucleic acid. A positive screening test is typically followed by confirmatory testing with toxin ELISA or a tissue-culture cytotoxicity assay to establish the presence of active toxin production.

For microbiological culture, cycloserine–cefoxitin–fructose agar (CCFA) serves as a selective and differential medium for isolating C. difficile from stool samples (Statement 3). In unclear or severe cases, sigmoidoscopy may reveal the characteristic pseudomembranous appearance with erythema, discrete white plaques, or adherent pseudomembranes.

Treatment begins with the immediate discontinuation of the inciting antibiotic whenever possible and placing the patient in isolation to limit transmission. First-line treatment for mild disease is a 10-day course of oral fidaxomicin, which is preferred because of its lower relapse rate; oral vancomycin is an acceptable alternative.

Severe or refractory cases may require adjunctive therapies such as intravenous immunoglobulin or glucocorticoids. For patients with recurrent CDI, fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is highly effective and works by restoring a healthy gut microbiota to prevent further relapses.

questions.text: 44. A young rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, and vomiting. He is also found to have nuchal rigidity and signs of raised intracranial pressure. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Pond herons can act as hosts

questions.solution:
The rice farmer presenting with features of acute encephalitis is likely to have Japanese encephalitis. Man is the incidental dead-end host.

The image shows the Culex mosquito. It can be identified by the presence of unspotted wings, hunched back, and the absence of stripes.  The Culex mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis.

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically C. tritaeniorhynchus and C. vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds (pond herons, cattle egret). Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

​​Actinomycosis is a slowly progressive, indolent infection characterized by suppurative and granulomatous inflammation. It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria and leads to pyogenic lesions that feature interconnecting sinus tracts and sulfur granules.

Actinomycosis manifests in various clinical forms: cervicofacial (most common, presenting as "lumpy jaw" with draining fistulas), thoracic (pulmonary infection with fever, cough, purulent sputum after aspiration/trauma), abdominal (post-appendix rupture/ulcer, affecting multiple organs), and pelvic (linked to IUDs). It can also spread to bones and surrounding tissues, causing multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis relies on Gram staining of sulfur granules, revealing a dense network of thin, gram-positive filaments surrounded by club-shaped structures, creating a "sunray appearance." Cultures exhibit a characteristic "molar tooth" appearance.

Penicillin G is the primary treatment. Alternative medications include amoxicillin, erythromycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, clindamycin, and minocycline.

questions.text: 47. An elderly diabetic patient with COVID-19 who was on invasive ventilation was given 40 mg of methylprednisolone for 7 days. After recovery, he developed facial pain and swelling. The tissue obtained from the sinuses showed the following finding. If amphotericin B is not available, which other drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing ribbon-like, irregular, aseptate hyphae is suggestive of mucormycosis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the first line of treatment. If Amphotericin B is not available, isavuconazole can be given to this patient.

Mucormycosis is a group of highly invasive, progressive, even life-threatening infections caused by fungi of the order Mucorales. Important fungi are rhizopus, mucor, actinomucor, etc.

These mucorales are present almost everywhere in the environment and humans are constantly exposed. But, infection is usually seen in immunocompromised states such as diabetes mellitus, glucocorticoid treatment, solid organ or hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and prolonged neutropenia. Recently, there was a rise in incidence of mucormycosis (which was already hyper-endemic in india) during the Covid 19 pandemic. 

It can present in five forms: Rhino-orbital-cerebral, pulmonary, cutaneous, gastrointestinal, or disseminated disease. Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form. The initial presentation is nonspecific with eye or facial pain and facial numbness followed by conjunctival suffusion and dimunition of vision. If untreated it can spread from the sinuses to the orbit, and to the frontal lobe, and may also cause cavernous sinus thrombosis. On examination, sinuses may look normal in initial stages. In later stages, there is erythema (with or without edema), followed by a necrotic eschar.

Diagnosis is made by culturing the organisms from the sterile sites like needle aspirate, pleural fluid, or a tissue biopsy specimen. The biopsy is most sensitive. It reveals characteristic wide, thick-walled, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles.

Management:

* Amphotericin B is the first line, antifungal agent. The dose of liposomal amphotericin formulation is 5-10mg/kg/day. Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole

questions.text: 49. A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. He gives a history of consuming stale food the previous day. Organism isolated on stool culture showed tumbling motility at 25°C and was non-motile at 37°C. Which among the following is the selective media for the above causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an adult with symptoms of gastroenteritis, history of consumption of stale food, organism showing tumbling motility at 25°C is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes. The selective media for Listeria monocytogenes is PALCAM agar.

The PALCAM agar is used to isolate Listeria monocytogenes. They show a grey-green with a black sunken center and a black halo on a cherry-red background. Stool culture is done in cold enrichment media. 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus. It shows characteristic tumbling motility at 25°C and becomes non-motile at 37°C. The image below shows the tumbling motility of Listeria.



Listeria can overcome the food preservation process since it grows at 4°C, low pH, and high salt concentration. 

Listeriosis can present as gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It usually develops within 48 hours of ingestion of a large inoculum in contaminated food like raw sprouts, unpasturized milk or soft cheeses. It can also lead to the formation of abscess, pharyngitis, pneumonia, and endocarditis. It leads to neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and meningoencephalitis in the elderly and immunocompromised people. Listeriosis in pregnancy can lead to abortion and stillbirth.

The virulence factor produced by Listeria is called listeriolysin O. This helps the bacteria to escape and causes septicemia. They are catalase-positive, will not produce H2S, and shows beta hemolysis. This helps to differentiate Listeria from other gran positive bacilli.

It is treated with ampicillin and gentamicin.

Other options:

Option A- PLET medium is used to culture Bacillus anthracis.

Option C- PPLO broth is used to culture Mycoplasma pneumonia

Option D- Cary Blair medium is used as a transport medium of Vibrio cholera, and Campylobacter.

questions.text: 50. During the evaluation of a 32-year-old HIV positive female with headache and nuchal stiffness, the CSF sample reveals the following on microscopic examination with India-ink staining. What is the most likely mode of acquiring this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of encapsulated yeast cells in CSF with India Ink staining are suggestive of Cryptococcosis which is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. It is an opportunistic fungus that is acquired by inhalation of yeast cells or spores which are found as a saprophyte in soil enriched with pigeon droppings.

In immunocompromised patients, the infection is acquired by inhalation of yeast cells or spores.

Cryptococcal meningitis and meningoencephalitis are the most vulnerable forms of cryptococcal infection. It is insidious in onset and often seen in AIDS patients. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in mononuclear cells and protein levels.

The diagnosis is made by the identification of yeast cells in CSF with India ink stain or by the detection of Cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination(CrAg).

Cryptococcosis in HIV patients needs aggressive therapy. It includes

* Induction therapy: IV or Liposomal Amphotericin B with Flucytosine daily for 2 weeks followed by fluconazole for at least 10 weeks.

* Maintenance therapy: Oral Fluconazole for a year or longer.



The given life cycle is of Cryptococcus species – Cryptococcus neoformans (common) and Cryptococcus gattii.

Other options:

Option A: Infection by tick-borne encephalitis viruses belonging to the Russian Spring-Summer Encephalitis complex are transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks.

Option B: Cat scratch disease is caused by Bartonella henselae. It presents as a febrile illness with lymphadenopathy following a cat scratch.

Option D: Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis caused by Naegleria fowleri is acquired by swimming in freshwater rivers or ponds. Naegleria invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges.
